perturbation.original_text:
“Trademarks” means trademarks, service marks, trade names, logos, slogans, trade dress or other source identifiers, including any
registration or any application for registration therefor, together with all goodwill associated therewith.
perturbation.changed_text:
“Trademarks” means trademarks, service marks, trade names, logos, slogans, trade dress or other source identifiers for products directly related to the SpinCo Business, including any
registration or any application for registration therefor, together with all goodwill associated therewith.
perturbation.explanation: The modified definition of “Trademarks” limits its scope to marks used on products directly related to the SpinCo Business. This creates a contradiction if, in another section (e.g., Section 4.01 regarding licenses from SpinCo to Honeywell), the term 'Trademarks' is used without this limitation, implying that the license covers all trademarks regardless of their connection to the SpinCo Business. This ambiguity can cause disputes over the scope of licensed trademarks.

perturbation.original_text:
(a) General. The Parties acknowledge that through the course of a history of integrated operations SpinCo and the members of the
SpinCo Group have each obtained knowledge of and access to, or otherwise used, certain Honeywell IP, including Patents, Trade Secrets, copyrighted
content, proprietary know-how, and other Intellectual Property Rights that are not otherwise governed expressly by the Separation Agreement or the
Ancillary Agreements or identified expressly in the schedules thereto (collectively, “Honeywell Shared IP”). With regard
perturbation.changed_text:
(a) General. The Parties acknowledge that through the course of a history of integrated operations SpinCo and the members of the
SpinCo Group may have incidentally obtained knowledge of and access to, or otherwise used, certain Honeywell IP, including Patents, Trade Secrets, copyrighted
content, proprietary know-how, and other Intellectual Property Rights that are not otherwise governed expressly by the Separation Agreement or the
Ancillary Agreements or identified expressly in the schedules thereto (collectively, “Honeywell Shared IP”). With regard
perturbation.explanation: By changing 'have each obtained knowledge of and access to, or otherwise used' to 'may have incidentally obtained knowledge of and access to, or otherwise used', the agreement casts doubt on whether SpinCo legitimately accessed Honeywell IP, weakening SpinCo’s claim to the Honeywell Shared IP licenses granted later in the section. If Section 5.02 states no implied licenses, this uncertainty about SpinCo’s initial access conflicts with the intent to grant licenses for previously used IP. This internal contradiction makes it difficult to establish a clear understanding of the rights and obligations regarding Honeywell Shared IP.
